Tel.: +358 294453451. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +358 294453446. Graphical abstract Ni additive in the three-way catalyst (TWC) has been known for its high activity in H2S suppression. However, the effect of Ni on the activity of TWC in stoichiometric exhaust gas conversion is less studied. In the present work characterization of bimetallic Pd–Ni catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3 or γ-Al2O3–La2O3 for potential TWC application was performed. The catalysts were prepared by wet co-impregnation and impregnation-evaporation methods. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET), X-ray diffraction (XRD), temperature-programmed reduction (TPR), UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectrometry (UV–vis DRS), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) techniques were employed to confirm the effect of Ni addition on the catalysts structure. XRD, TPR, and STEM characterization was employed in order to evaluate the presence of Pd–Ni interaction. The activity of the catalysts was tested in the oxidation reaction of CO and C3H6 under stoichiometric conditions. Based on the obtained results, we confirmed the structure of prepared catalysts and the effect of Pd–Ni interaction on the catalytic activity of Pd–Ni catalysts in CO and C3H6 oxidation. XRD and TPR characterization suggested that Pd and Ni are competing for the support sites. The observed competition affected Pd-support and Ni-support interactions and consequently activity. Fresh bimetallic catalysts had higher catalytic activity compared to monometallic ones due to higher active metal loading and the presence of NiO phase. It was concluded that the catalytic activity of aged bimetallic catalysts is not affected by the addition of Ni. For that reason, addition of Ni as a second metal to Pd-based catalysts for TWC reactions can be considered in the future studies. Keywords Pd–Ni bimetallic catalysts TWC Al2O3 NiAl2O4 spinel CO and propene oxidation 1 Introduction Improvement of the air quality has been a hot research topic for the past few decades. One of the factors affecting the quality of the air is pollution of air with exhaust gases. Carbon monoxide, short hydrocarbons, and nitrogen oxides are the main pollutants produced by the vehicles running on conventional petroleum fuels. To reduce production of the toxic gases, electric engines and biofuels appeared as an alternative to commonly used petroleum fuels. Nevertheless, the number of vehicles running on petroleum fuels increases continuously. For that reason, development of catalysts for exhaust gas conversion still remains to be an important research topic. For the reduction of exhaust gas emissions in the gasoline fueled engines, a three-way catalytic converter (TWC) has been developed. The operational principle of the TWC is simultaneous conversion of CO, C x H y , and NO x pollutants. The highest conversion of exhaust gases can be achieved when TWC operates in air-fuel ratio close to stoichiometric value [1,2]. In general, commercial catalytic converters contain an active component deposited on the high surface area support, and promoters for better performance and longer life-time [1,3–7]. Platinum, palladium, and rhodium are commonly used metals in the catalytic conversion of exhaust gases [8–11]. Aluminum oxide, cerium oxide, zirconium oxide, and their combinations are well-known support materials for the noble metal catalysts [12–14]. CeO2–ZrO2 mixed oxides are frequently added as oxygen storage promoters, and Ba or La oxides as the promoters for thermal stability of the support [15–20]. Nowadays the tendency in development of catalysts for the exhaust gas conversion is directed toward the search of active and relatively inexpensive materials. Modern catalysts are expected to possess higher activity during a cold start and better long term stability. In particular, palladium has appeared to be a common choice of catalyst for those reactions. Such a choice is due to its high activity in the low-temperature oxidation reactions and lower price compared with other noble metals [21–25]. However, the rising price of palladium and the deactivation of palladium catalysts during the long term work increase the demand in improvements of the existent catalysts. One possible solution of increasing the catalyst life-time is the modification of existing catalysts by addition of a second metal. Commonly, the second metal is chosen from groups 9–11 in the periodic table [26–29]. Among those metals, nickel has been proven to affect catalytic activity for exhaust gas treatment, while having comparably lower price than noble metals [27,30,31]. Ni has been widely employed as a sulfur scavenger in TWC due to its high activity in H2S removal [32,33]. A possible concern in Ni addition to the TWC system may arise due to potential danger of Ni-carbonyl formation. Nonetheless, if Ni-containing TWC is installed in the closed-coupled position near the car engine, the operational temperature of the converter is clearly higher than the decomposition temperature of Ni-carbonyl. Considering comparably low amount of Ni in catalysts and the presence of other active metals capable of binding CO, the possibility of Ni-carbonyl formation is very low. Therefore, application of Ni as a second metal for additional TWC reactions can be considered for converters in the closed-coupled position. Prior to evaluating the role of Ni as a second metal, the effect of Ni on the activity of initial catalyst should be examined. It is important to verify that Ni addition will not deteriorate initial catalyst activity. Beside the application of Ni as a sulfur scavenger a few studies have been conducted on the bimetallic Pd–Ni automotive exhaust catalysts operating under the stoichiometric conditions [26,27,30,31,34]. Bimetallic catalysts have been prepared with total metal loading of 2wt.%. Catalytic activities of Pd–Ni/Al2O3 catalysts in stoichiometric CO and NO elimination have been unaffected by the presence of Ni [31]. Improved catalytic activity in CO oxidation has been obtained on Pd–Ni catalysts supported on alumina modified with Ce–Zr mixed oxide. It has been concluded that the presence of Ni enhanced the interaction of Pd and Ce–Zr mixed oxide, resulting in a better catalyst performance [27,31,34]. Nonetheless, no improvement on the catalytic activity has been detected on the aged Pd–Ni catalysts [27]. Although Pd and Ni belong to the same group in the periodic table, they were found to behave differently on the alumina support surface. Palladium is dispersed over the support in the form of PdO x and tends to aggregate when exposed to high temperatures [35]. On the other hand, high temperatures improve interaction between nickel and alumina support leading to the formation of spinel-like NiAl2O4 structure [36,37]. Therefore, it could be expected that co-addition of Pd and Ni would result in the formation of separate phases of PdO x deposited on the support and of NiAl2O4 spinel. Nevertheless, the presence of Pd–Ni interaction has been detected on the bimetallic Pd–Ni catalysts with the total metal loading above 7wt.% [38,39]. Bimetallic Pd–Ni catalysts have been found to have a superior catalytic activity than corresponding monometallic catalysts [40–42]. The improved catalytic activity has been explained by an interaction between Pd and Ni and increase in the metal surface area [39,40]. The discovered Pd–Ni interaction improved the reducibility of both Ni and Pd metals leading to a higher catalytic activity. For that reason, the determination of the nature of Pd–Ni interaction as well as factors affecting it could help to further improve the catalytic activity of Pd–Ni catalysts. The aim of the present study is to examine the effect of the nickel addition on the activity and stability of Pd based catalyst in CO and C3H6 oxidation reactions under stoichiometric conditions. Multiple factors affecting Pd–Ni interaction will be considered. For the bimetallic catalysts preparation two Pd precursors (Pd nitrate and acetylacetonate) and two supports (γ-Al2O3 and Al2O3–La2O3) will be used. Furthermore, influence of the concentration of Ni and calcination temperature on the catalysts structure will be examined. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A set of bimetallic Pd–Ni catalysts was prepared by the wet impregnation method. Pd(acac)2 or Pd(NO3)2 in HNO3 water solution (18.12wt.% Pd) were chosen as an active metal source. Nickel was introduced in a form of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O precursor. Palladium loading was adjusted to 3wt.% for each of the catalysts and Pd:Ni ratio was 1:0, 1:1 or 1:3wt.%. γ-Al2O3 (Sasol, particle size distribution <25μm 37.8%, <45μm 64.4%, and <90μm 92.0%) or γ-Al2O3 promoted with La2O3 (3wt.% La2O3, particle size distribution <25μm 36.4%, <45μm 64.4%, and <90μm 98.6%) were employed as a support material. Propionic acid (Fluka, p.a.) was used as the impregnation solvent for Pd(acac)2 precursor, while HNO3 water solution was used for Pd(NO3)2. Pd and Ni nitrate precursors were deposited simultaneously on the support by co-impregnation method, while Pd(acac)2 and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O precursors were deposited by impregnation-evaporation method. Precursors were mixed with a support under continuous stirring at room temperature for 24h, followed by evaporation of the solvent at 145°C for 10h. Calcination was carried out in air at 550°C for 2h, the resulting catalysts were denoted as fresh. A portion of each fresh catalyst was aged in air at 900°C for 4h. The preparation procedure of both the co-impregnation and the impregnation–evaporation methods was exactly the same. The difference in the method name arises from the physical properties of Ni nitrate precursor, which is insoluble in organic acids. However, its melting point is below the solvent evaporation temperature (T =145°C). Therefore, Pd(acac)2 precursor was dissolved in propionic acid and deposited to the support by impregnation. The deposition of co-added Ni(NO3)2·6H2O precursor occurred during drying step by evaporation. For studies of the effect of nickel on the γ-Al2O3 support, monometallic 3 and 9wt.% Ni catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation and evaporation methods. Drying, calcination and aging steps were carried out under the same conditions as described above. Reference NiO sample was prepared by calcining Ni(NO3)2·6H2O precursor in oven at 550°C for 2h. Formation of NiO phase was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction analysis. The catalysts prepared for the experiments are denoted as A-Nix, A-Nix-La, N-Nix and N-Nix-La, Table 1 . Where A refer to Pd(acac)2 and N to Pd(NO3)2 precursor. La refers to γ-Al2O3 promoted with La2O3 and x is the loading of Ni in catalyst. Reference Ni/Al2O3 samples were denoted as yNi-P and yNi-W, where y is the Ni weight loading, P stands for propionic acid and W for water impregnation solvent. Further, catalysts containing 3wt.% of Ni will be referred as low Ni content and catalysts with 9wt.% of Ni as high Ni content catalysts. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The specific surface areas of the catalysts were measured by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller method (BET) with a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 device. Prior to the experiment, a portion of each catalyst (220mg) was pretreated under vacuum at 350°C for 3h. The measurements were carried out at the temperature of liquid nitrogen using nitrogen gas as an adsorbate. Each catalyst was tested three times. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded with a Bruker-AXD D8 Advance device using Cu Kα as a radiation source. The diffraction patterns were recorded at 2θ angle range from 12° to 90° with a scanning speed of 0.11°min−1. The PdO crystallite sizes were estimated with TOPAS software on the basis of the XRD patterns [43]. Measurement of the metal dispersion by common CO and H2 chemisorption methods is more challenging for Pd–Ni bimetallic catalysts, since CO and H2 molecules can be chemisorbed on both Pd and Ni. To avoid misinterpretation of the results, Pd dispersion was calculated on the basis of PdO crystallite size. Firstly specific metal surface area was calculated from PdO crystallite size obtained from XRD measurements: (1) A m = χ ⋅ f 100 ⋅ ρ ⋅ d , where A m is the specific metal surface area (m2 g−1), χ is the percent metal loading (3wt.% for Pd), f is a shape factor (6 for sphere), ρ is Pd density (12.02×10−6 gm−3), and d is PdO crystallite size (m). Metal dispersion was calculated from Eq. (2): (2) δ = M A m A x ⋅ L A v 100 χ 100 % , where δ is the metal dispersion (%), M is the molecular weight of the metal (gmol−1), A x is a cross-sectional area of each atom (m2), L Av is Avogadro's number (6.022×1023) [44]. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR-H2) measurements were performed with a Quantachrome autosorb ASiQwin device. The samples were pretreated at 300°C for 2h under continuous N2 flow (30cm3 min−1) and then cooled to room temperature. After cooling, the gas was changed to 10% H2 in argon and TPR measurement was performed by heating the samples from room temperature to 1000°C (10°Cmin−1). TPR profiles were recorded using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and quadrupole mass spectrometer (Pfeiffer PrismaPlus™ Mass Spectrometer). Water, formed during reduction, was collected before the TCD in a cold trap. Diffuse reflectance UV–vis (UV–vis DRS) spectra were recorded with a Perkin Elmer Lambda 900 UV/VIS/NIR spectrometer in a range of 200–850nm with 0.1nmmin−1 scanning speed. Surface images of the samples were recorded with a Hitachi S4800 FE-SEM (scanning electron microscopy). The Thermo Electron Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDS) device was used to analyze the surface composition. The following working parameters were used in the EDS measurements: 20kV accelerating voltage and 10μA current at 15mm working distance. Detailed surface characterization of the catalysts was performed with a JEOL JEM-2100F scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM), operated at 200kV acceleration voltage coupled with Thermo Electron EDS device. Prior to STEM characterization, small amount of samples was suspended in ethanol and then deposited on lacey carbon film supported on a copper grid. Prior to the activity measurement, the catalysts were pretreated under nitrogen flow at 550°C for 1h. Following the purification, the reaction gas was fed into the reactor. The stoichiometric mixture of 700ppmC3H6, 8500ppm CO, 0.74mol% O2 balanced with N2 (AGA) was used as the reaction gas. Under the reaction gas flow, the samples were heated from room temperature to 350°C at a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1. The gaseous reaction products were collected at 25°C intervals. Concentrations of CO, N2, O2, C3H6, and CO2 gases in the reactor outlet were measured with a HP 6890 Plus gas chromatograph (GC). The conversion of CO and C3H6 (%) was calculated from Eq. (3): (3) X conversion = ( X ) i n − ( X ) o u t ( X ) i n ⋅ 100 % , where (X) in is the concentration of CO or C3H6 gas flowing into the reactor ((CO)in =0.85%, (C3H6)in =0.07%,), (X) out is the concentration of CO or C3H6 gas flowing out of the reactor. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 BET The results of the BET surface area measurements are summarized in Table 2 . Catalysts supported on Al2O3–La2O3 have initially lower surface area than catalysts supported on Al2O3. The surface area loss after aging is lower for the samples containing La2O3. Bimetallic catalysts have lower surface area than monometallic Pd catalysts, and with increasing Ni concentration surface area of the catalysts decreases. The largest surface area loss after addition of Ni was detected for the fresh A-Nix catalysts. 3.2 XRD The X-ray diffraction patterns for the fresh and aged bimetallic catalysts are shown in Figs. 1 and 2 . The X-ray diffraction patterns of the fresh catalysts with low Ni content reveals the presence of PdO and Al2O3 characteristic peaks, shown in Fig. 1a. No characteristic peaks of Ni or NiO were detected. The absence of NiO peaks has been previously explained by the high degree of NiO dispersion due to strong metal-support interaction [27,42]. In the case of aged catalyst with low Ni content additional diffraction peaks of metallic Pd were observed, Fig. 1b. NiO diffraction intensities at 2θ values of 43° and 63.4° appear in the diffraction patterns of the fresh catalysts when the Ni concentration increases to 9wt.%, as presented in Fig. 2a. The shoulders are more noticeable for catalysts prepared from Pd nitrate precursor. Furthermore, area of NiO peaks in catalysts supported on Al2O3–La2O3 is larger compared to catalysts on pure Al2O3. On the XRD pattern of A-Ni9 Fresh catalyst peaks of NiO are of much lower area compared to N-Ni9. Addition of La2O3 to alumina support reduced the amount of metallic Pd in aged catalysts, Fig. 2b. The changes in catalysts structure after addition of nickel are more discoverable when comparing XRD patterns of catalysts with increasing concentration of nickel, Fig. 3 . Prepared Ni-P and Ni-W samples containing 3 and 9wt.% of Ni had light green coloration after calcination at 550°C. The color changed to light blue after aging at 900°C. The change in the color suggests formation of a pseudo-spinel phase or NiO in the fresh catalysts and a NiAl2O4 spinel phase in the aged catalysts [37]. Formation of the spinel phase after aging can be observed on the XRD patterns of aged catalysts with the slight shift of the support peak at ≈66° toward lower 2θ values, Fig. 3b. Similar shift for the fresh catalysts is less detectable Fig. 3a. Characteristic peaks of NiO species were not detected on the 9Ni-P and 9Ni-W samples in contrast to the fresh bimetallic catalysts. Based on that observation Ni is expected to be in well dispersed or spinel state in the monometallic Ni/Al2O3 samples. The XRD patterns of Ni-P and Ni-W catalysts were identical and, therefore, samples prepared from both solvents had identical crystalline phases present. The PdO crystallite sizes were estimated on the basis of the XRD peak of PdO (101) at 2θ value of 34°. The results are presented in Table 2. PdO crystallite size ranges from 3 to 8nm for the fresh catalysts, and from 14 to 18nm for the aged catalysts. After aging, the PdO crystallite size increases by nearly an equivalent factor of 10nm for all of the catalysts. Bimetallic A-Nix catalysts have larger PdO crystallites than N-Nix catalysts. The larger size of PdO crystallites on the bimetallic A-Nix catalysts compared to N-Nix can be explained by the catalyst preparation method. For N-Nix catalysts prepared by co-impregnation, Pd and Ni precursors were dissolved in the solvent and deposited on the support; therefore interaction of both metals with the support occurred simultaneously. The competition between Pd and Ni for the support sites led to the formation of oxides with larger crystallite sizes than in the monometallic samples. In the case of A-Nix catalysts, Pd(acac)2 precursor have decomposition temperature higher than the solvent evaporation temperature. For that reason, during the solvent evaporation step, dominantly Ni precursor could form a structure with the support. Pd(acac)2 started to decompose to form PdO in the calcination step, when Ni precursor had already been decomposed. Therefore less surface sites are available on the support for Pd, which leads to the formation of larger PdO crystallites on the A-Nix catalysts. Catalysts containing La promoter had initially lower surface area (Table 2), and thus lower amount of the surface sites was available. Hence, NiO and PdO crystallites of larger size were detected on the catalysts promoted with La. Pd dispersion was calculated on the basis of PdO crystallite size and summarized in Table 2. Pd dispersion decreases with increasing Ni content due to the formation of larger PdO crystallites. The fresh catalysts show a higher Pd dispersion in comparison with the aged samples. In the case of the aged catalyst palladium sinters and, as a result, the amount of Pd nanoparticles decreases. 3.3 TPR-H2 Fig. 4 shows reference TPR profiles of Pd catalysts and NiO powder. TPR profiles of monometallic Pd catalysts display a single peak of H2 evolution at 80–90°C for decomposition of Pd hydride [45], Fig. 4a. Addition of La2O3 to both fresh and aged catalysts results in the formation of one new reduction peak at 300–340°C. The peak has been previously attributed to the partial reduction of La2O3 interacting strongly with PdO [46,47]. Reduction of NiO powder produces a small peak of reduction of surface NiO x species at 350°C and a large peak of bulk NiO reduction at 400°C, Fig. 4b. Monometallic Ni samples have two reduction peaks in the TPR profile, as shown in Fig. 5 . In the previous works it has been concluded that the peak at lower temperature is the reduction of highly dispersed NiO, while peak at higher temperature is the reduction of pseudo-spinel or spinel NiAl2O4 structure [36,48–51]. Reduction peaks of 9wt.% Ni–Al2O3 samples have higher intensity compared to 3wt.% Ni–Al2O3. Therefore, the presence of both peaks is expected to be due to the reduction of Ni species. Based on the color of Ni–Al2O3 powders and on the XRD measurements, it can be concluded that the reduction peak at about 820°C of the fresh samples is due to reduction of the pseudo-spinel phase and peak above 900°C of the aged samples is due to reduction of the spinel phase. The reduction peak at 650°C appears at much higher temperature compared to bulk NiO and, additionally, no bulk NiO phase was detected on XRD patterns of Ni–Al2O3 samples. Those observations suggest the presence of different NiO phase, which is reducible at higher temperature than bulk NiO. The reduction of NiO at higher temperature can occur when Ni species are interacting with the support, forming a stronger Ni-support bond and, thus, increasing the reduction temperature. Therefore, peak at 650°C would be due to reduction of well dispersed NiO [36,52], and hereafter would be marked as NiO-S. The position of the peaks of samples with higher Ni content is shifted toward lower temperatures compared to samples with lower Ni content. Thus, increasing concentration of Ni improves the reducibility of Ni species. The ratio between two reduction peaks of 9Ni-P and 9Ni-W samples is different, suggesting that preparation method affects the formation of different Ni species. After reduction the color of the monometallic Ni samples changed to brown-gray, indicating the reduction of Ni oxide species to metallic nickel. TPR profiles of the fresh and aged bimetallic A-Nix and N-Nix catalysts are presented in Fig. 6 . Reduction of the fresh catalysts results in appearance of one H2 evolution peak at 90°C (peak 1) and three H2 consumption peaks at 450, 630 and 780°C (peaks 2, 3, 4). Reduction of aged samples produces similar H2 evolution peak (1) and only one H2 consumption peak at 820°C (peak 4). H2 evolution peak 1 can be attributed to the decomposition of Pd hydride as it was detected in the monometallic Pd catalysts. Peak 2 appears in the same temperature region as bulk NiO in the TPR of the reference NiO powder. In the earlier studies it has been suggested that reduction of NiO weakly bound to the support produces peak below 600°C, and the reduction of NiO strongly bound to the support results in the peak above 600°C [52]. Therefore, the peak 2 is due to the reduction of bulk NiO species, while the peak 3 can be attributed to the reduction of well-dispersed NiO-S species. High temperature reduction peak 4 of the fresh catalysts is expected to appear due to the reduction of the pseudo-spinel phase and peak 4 of the aged catalysts is due to reduction of the spinel phase [36,38,52]. The intensity of the peaks corresponding to the Ni species reduction increases with the increasing concentration of nickel. Comparison of TPR profiles of monometallic Ni (Fig. 5) and bimetallic Pd–Ni catalysts (Fig. 6) reveals that all Ni related peaks are shifted toward lower temperatures compared to monometallic catalysts. Based on the latter observation, it can be concluded that co-addition of Pd with Ni improves the reducibility of Ni species. TPR profiles of catalysts prepared from different Pd precursors have differences in the position and intensity of Ni reduction peaks. Fresh A-Ni9 catalyst has peak 2 of lower intensity than N-Ni9 catalyst, while peaks 3 and 4 of A-Nix catalysts have higher intensity compared to N-Nix catalysts. For the aged catalysts the effect of Pd precursor on the intensity of the spinel reduction peak (4) is less pronounced. Reduction peaks of N-Nix catalysts are positioned at slightly lower temperatures compared to A-Nix catalysts, which can suggest better reducibility of Ni species in N-Nix catalysts. Bimetallic catalysts containing La promoter had an additional reduction peak (5) at 320°C, which is attributed to the partial reduction of La2O3 interacting strongly with PdO [46,47], shown in Fig. 7 . The presence of La in the fresh A-Ni9-La and N-Ni9-La catalysts affects the intensity of peaks 2 and 3. Peak 2 of La containing fresh catalysts is of higher intensity, compared to catalysts without La, which implies higher amount of bulk NiO in La containing bimetallic catalysts. Evaluation of La containing catalysts prepared from different Pd precursors leads to similar conclusions done for catalysts without La promoter, N-Nix-La catalysts have better reducibility of Ni species than A-Nix-La catalysts. The peak 2 appears only when the Ni content in the fresh catalysts is high. Hence, it can be suggested that peak 2 is originated from the excess amount of NiO on the support. Those results can be supported by the XRD measurements, where NiO peaks were distinguished only on the fresh catalysts with high Ni content. XRD patterns of the fresh catalysts with low Ni content had no visible NiO peaks (Fig. 1a), and in the TPR profiles peak 2 below 500°C is almost undistinguishable (Figs. 6a and 7a). Moreover, XRD patterns of the fresh catalysts with high Ni content supported on Al2O3–La2O3 had NiO peaks of larger area compared to similar catalysts on pure Al2O3 (Fig. 2a). Similarly, peak 2 on the TPR profiles of the fresh A-Ni9-La and N-Ni9-La catalysts was of higher intensity than on A-Ni9 and N-Ni9 catalysts (Fig. 7a). Therefore, peak 2 in the TPR profiles of the fresh catalysts with high Ni content is expected to appear due to bulk NiO. Reduction peak of bulk NiO was not present in the TPR profiles of the monometallic Ni catalysts (Fig. 5). For that reason it can be assumed that the formation of bulk NiO in the bimetallic catalysts with high Ni content is due to the competition of Pd and Ni for the surface sites. The conclusion can be supported by the physical properties of compounds used for catalysts preparation. Deposition of Pd and Ni nitrate precursors is a competitive reaction, since both precursors start to decompose on the support simultaneously. As a result, N-Ni9 catalysts had larger NiO and PdO crystallites compared to monometallic Ni and Pd catalysts. On the other hand, Pd(acac)2 and Ni(NO3)2 precursors, used for A-Nix catalysts preparation, dissolve and decompose differently under preparation conditions. Ni nitrate in A-Nix catalysts start to decompose first to form Ni–alumina structure during the drying step. Decomposition of Pd(acac)2 occurs during the calcination step. The number of surface sites is thus less for PdO formation on the support. The surface area of La stabilized alumina is smaller, compared to pure alumina, which leads to the formation of large NiO and PdO crystallites, as it was detected by XRD. Aging of the bimetallic catalysts leads to a stronger Ni-support interaction and peaks 2 and 3 are not present in the TPR profiles of the aged catalysts where all Ni exists in the form of spinel, Figs. 6 and 7. Obtained TPR and XRD results can further support conclusions made on the catalysts preparation methods used in the current work. Investigation of XRD patterns of A-Nix catalysts revealed less visible NiO peaks compared to N-Nix catalysts. From TPR results it was seen that A-Nix catalysts had lower intensity peak of bulk NiO reduction than N-Nix catalysts. On the other hand, the intensity of the NiAl2O4 reduction peak was higher for A-Nix catalysts. The later observations proved that in A-Nix catalysts Ni–alumina structure is formed earlier and PdO is formed later, which resulted in the presence of larger PdO crystallites compared to N-Nix catalysts. The quantitative analysis of TPR results based on H2 consumption was omitted since only one component of the bimetallic system could be characterized. The reason is the absence of PdO reduction peak in the TPR profiles of Pd-containing catalysts. PdO was reduced during stabilization of the TCD signal and, for that reason, PdO reduction was not recorded. Additionally, in the TPR profiles of monometallic Ni catalysts some peaks of Ni reduction were seen only partly, preventing adequate integration. Therefore, only Ni component on the bimetallic catalysts could be characterized by using calibration. 3.4 UV–vis Reference UV–vis DRS profiles of NiO powder and Ni-W samples are presented in Fig. 8 . Based on the reference NiO sample and earlier reports, bands at 370–380 and 715–720nm can be assigned to the octahedrally coordinated Ni2+ species in NiO lattice. The octahedral Ni2+ species in Al2O3 lattice have been found at 420–430nm, while the tetrahedral Ni2+ species in Al2O3 lattice (NiAl2O4 spinel) have been found at 550–555 and 600–645nm range [49,53,54]. Characteristic bands of the tetrahedral Ni2+ species in Al2O3 lattice were present in both fresh and aged Ni-W samples, however the bands intensity was lower in the case of the fresh samples. Additionally, fresh samples had broad bands in the range of 350–450 and 700–800nm typical for octahedral Ni2+ species. The latter observations support conclusions from XRD and TPR measurements, where Ni was found in the form of NiO and pseudo-spinel in the fresh samples, while the NiAl2O4 spinel phase was dominant in the aged samples. UV–vis DRS spectra of Ni-P samples were identical to the spectra of Ni-W (not shown). UV–vis DRS spectra of the bimetallic A-Nix-La and A-Ni9 catalysts are shown in Fig. 9 . New absorption bands in the ranges of 250–300 and 400–500nm can be assigned to palladium-oxygen charge transfer and d–d transitions, respectively [35]. On the spectra of the fresh bimetallic catalysts bands corresponding to Ni species are almost indistinguishable. Bands of the tetrahedral Ni in the range of 550–650nm are visible for A-Ni9 and A-Ni9-La catalysts. In the case of aged catalysts the presence of the tetrahedral Ni species is more pronounced, Fig. 9b. Similar observations were made for the UV–vis DRS spectra of N-Nix and N-Nix-La (not shown). 3.5 SEM/EDS The catalysts surface composition was estimated with the EDS device by the line-scan method. The recorded SEM images and the EDS data of A-Ni9-La catalysts are shown in Fig. 10 with a yellow arrow representing the line for EDS scan. Examination of the recorded images suggests that palladium particles are distributed irregularly on the support surface. Only separate PdO x particles are presented on the surface of fresh catalysts, whereas on the aged catalysts can be found aggregated PdO x particles. The surface of bimetallic catalysts was carefully examined on the presence of bulk NiO particles. EDS analysis revealed that Ni is equally distributed on the catalysts surface of both fresh and aged catalysts, Fig. 10c and d. 3.6 STEM STEM/EDS analysis of the fresh bimetallic catalysts revealed the presence of separate PdO x particles. NiO particles were not found even on the catalysts with 9wt.% Ni loading. It was possible to separate spectral images of the bimetallic catalysts into two phases, Fig. 11 . First phase clearly indicated the presence of both Al and Ni elements, while the second phase consisted predominantly of Pd. The presence of observed phases proves the existence of NiAl2O4 or well dispersed NiO phase on the catalysts surface, as a major amount of Ni is concentrated on the alumina support. 3.7 Activity tests Catalytic activities of the prepared catalysts are presented in terms of light-off temperatures of 50% conversion of CO and C3H6, Figs. 12 and 13 . Obtained results indicate the effect of Ni on the catalytic activity of fresh catalysts. In the case of Pd(acac)2 precursor the presence of Ni has a minor effect on the light-off temperatures. Increase in the light-off in the presence of Ni can be explained by the formation of larger PdO crystallites and decrease of the Pd dispersion estimated from XRD measurements. Slightly lower light-off temperatures of the fresh A-Ni9 and A-Ni9-La catalysts can be due to the presence of bulk NiO confirmed by TPR and XRD measurements. Bimetallic catalysts prepared from Pd(NO3)2 precursor visibly decrease the light-off temperature with the increasing concentration of Ni. One reason could be a higher active metal loading of the bimetallic catalysts compared to monometallic catalysts. Furthermore, improvement in the catalytic activity of the fresh N-Nix catalysts might be due to the presence of bulk NiO and better reducibility of Ni species, confirmed by XRD and TPR measurements on N-Ni9 and N-Ni9-La catalysts. The intensity of the peak corresponding to bulk NiO increased in order A-Ni9<A-Ni9-La<N-Ni9<N-Ni9-La, which correlates with the decrease of light-off temperature for the same samples. On the contrary to the fresh catalysts, catalytic activities of the aged samples remained unchanged regardless of the nickel concentration. That kind of result can be explained by the loss of bulk NiO and the formation of NiAl2O4 spinel phase, which is more stable and does not take part in the oxidation reaction. Addition of La2O3 further enhanced catalytic activity of the fresh catalysts, though it had minor effect on the activity of aged catalysts. 4 Conclusions The structure of the prepared bimetallic Pd–Ni catalysts was confirmed by XRD, TPR, UV–vis DRS, SEM and STEM measurements. XRD and TPR analysis revealed the presence of NiO and pseudo-spinel phases on the fresh bimetallic catalysts, while predominantly NiAl2O4 spinel phase was detected on the aged catalysts. With the aid of TPR measurements it was concluded that the fresh bimetallic catalysts contained two NiO phases: one of bulk NiO weakly bound to the support and another of well-dispersed NiO strongly bound to the support. Using STEM/EDS measurements it was found that on the catalysts surface Ni and Al were concentrated in similar catalyst domains, while Pd occupied different domains. It was concluded that A-Nix catalysts had weaker interaction between Pd and support compared to N-Nix catalysts. It can be suggested that use of organic acids as an impregnation solvents and Pd(acac)2 precursor can improve Ni-support interaction, however weaken Pd-support interaction. Characterization of bimetallic catalysts revealed that the expected Pd–Ni interaction is present in a form of competition between Pd and Ni for the support sites. Based on the XRD and TPR observations it was concluded that the amount of weakly and strongly bound NiO on the support is influenced by the competition between Pd and Ni precursors during catalyst preparation. The presence of Pd–Ni competition for the support sites affected the crystallite sizes of both Pd and Ni components. Moreover, preparation of the bimetallic catalysts with Al2O3–La2O3 support resulted in even stronger Pd–Ni competition. Lower surface area of Al2O3–La2O3 support provided less sites for Pd and Ni adsorption, thus increasing the competition and crystallite sizes of PdO and NiO. Addition of Ni improved the catalytic activity of the fresh N-Nix and N-Nix-La catalysts in CO and C3H6 oxidation. Improvement of the catalytic activity was explained by higher active metal loading, the presence of NiO phase, and improved reducibility of Ni species. In the contrast, A-Nix and A-Nix-La catalysts had lower Pd dispersion and NiO phase was reducible at higher temperatures. The aforementioned factors led to decrease in the catalytic activity of A-Nix catalysts after addition of Ni. Catalytic activities of the aged catalysts in oxidation reaction of CO and C3H6 were not affected by the presence of Ni due to formation of more stable NiAl2O4 spinel structure. Therefore, Ni can be added to Pd catalyst as a second metal for the additional reactions of exhaust gas treatment without decreasing catalytic activity of the initial catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Ni additive in the three-way catalyst (TWC) has been known for its high activity in H2S suppression. However, the effect of Ni on the activity of TWC in stoichiometric exhaust gas conversion is less studied. In the present work characterization of bimetallic Pd–Ni catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3 or γ-Al2O3–La2O3 for potential TWC application was performed. The catalysts were prepared by wet co-impregnation and impregnation-evaporation methods. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET), X-ray diffraction (XRD), temperature-programmed reduction (TPR), UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectrometry (UV–vis DRS), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) techniques were employed to confirm the effect of Ni addition on the catalysts structure. XRD, TPR, and STEM characterization was employed in order to evaluate the presence of Pd–Ni interaction. The activity of the catalysts was tested in the oxidation reaction of CO and C3H6 under stoichiometric conditions. Based on the obtained results, we confirmed the structure of prepared catalysts and the effect of Pd–Ni interaction on the catalytic activity of Pd–Ni catalysts in CO and C3H6 oxidation. XRD and TPR characterization suggested that Pd and Ni are competing for the support sites. The observed competition affected Pd-support and Ni-support interactions and consequently activity. Fresh bimetallic catalysts had higher catalytic activity compared to monometallic ones due to higher active metal loading and the presence of NiO phase. It was concluded that the catalytic activity of aged bimetallic catalysts is not affected by the addition of Ni. For that reason, addition of Ni as a second metal to Pd-based catalysts for TWC reactions can be considered in the future studies.
coredata.dc:title: Preparation and characterization of Pd–Ni bimetallic catalysts for CO and C3H6 oxidation under stoichiometric conditions
